newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: S&P sees better Australasian dairy credit quality.
newsitem.headline: S&P sees better Australasian dairy credit quality.

text.p: Australasian diary companies have posted improved credit quality due to mergers and acquisitions, regulatory changes and export growth, ratings agency Standard and Poor's said on Friday.
S&P associate director Brenda Wardlaw said recent mergers and acquisitions in particular had led to efficiency gains through rationalisation of processing plants.

"Rationalisation has also increased as a result of changes in the share structure of the New Zealand Dairy Board, progressive deregulation of the liquid milk market in Australia, and increased milk supply in both countries," Wardlaw said.
Export growth opportunities from increased access to key markets and subsidy cuts in the European Union and other producers countries were also positive.
S&P said total world consumption of dairy products was forecast to rise at one-to-two percent a year for the next five years, but growth rates in the Asian region were expected to be much higher.

The traditionally sound credit quality of Australasian dairy companies reflected the global cost competitiveness of the Australian and New Zealand dairy industries, and the system of paying creditors in supplier-owned companies.
Australia's two listed dairy companies are National Foods Ltd and QUF Industries Ltd.
Supplier owned companies are Bonlac Foods Ltd, Murray Goulburn Co-operative Ltd and Australian Co-Operative Foods Ltd (ACF),
In New Zealandm recent mergers have led to two companies accounting for more than 74 percent of the processed milk market -- New Zealand Co-Operative Dairy Co Ltd and Kiwi Co-operative Dairies Ltd.
